text:
This includes stuff like office.dll and stuff related to the VS.NET.  Some 
peole don't need these, nor have these products even installed.

Perhaps there could be a minimal default list of the libraries that are part of 
the core SDK, and maybe an extended list that people can request if they want 
it.
creator: francisu@ieee.org
steve_l@iseran.com
text:
well, I just took nearly all of the managed code libs in  
C:\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v1.0.3705
on the basis that they were common and I didnt want to have to worry about 
which ones to include. Which ones should I omit

remember, you can always exclude all references then use a nested reference 
path to pull them in

office.dll is not in C:\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v1.0.3705, at least on 
my machine, so I think this should be excluded for sure.  I think its probably 
the wrapper for the office tlb.

What I suggest is mscorlib and all of the System.* dlls and nothing else.  This 
will make sure the base stuff works for everyone.
creator: francisu@ieee.org

text:
so you think I should pull the non system stuff:

            "Accessibility.dll;" +
            "cscompmgd.dll;" +
            "CustomMarshalers.dll;" +
            "IEExecRemote.dll;" +
            "IEHost.dll;" +
            "IIEHost.dll;" +
            "ISymWrapper.dll;" +
            "Microsoft.JScript.dll;" +
            "Microsoft.VisualBasic.dll;" +
            "Microsoft.VisualC.dll;" +
            "Microsoft.Vsa.dll;" +
            "office.dll;" +
            "RegCode.dll;" +

I worry about the first three of these; i.e. I dont know what they are...the 
rest can be pulled. It's easier to add a library when the compiler complains, 
than to have it whine that a dll is missing.

life would be easier if they had used new extensions for libs and apps; not 
just for fileset based inclusion of managed DLLs, omitting native libs, but 
because I think the idea of having some exes safe to download if you use IE 
only is a social engineering security risk
creator: steve_l@iseran.com

text:
I agree with you, I would leave the first 3 on the list in; although I have not 
needed them, it seems they are really part of the .NET framework and should 
probably be in there.

The rest should go.

Thanks.
creator: francisu@ieee.org

text:
Fixed in the ANT_15_RELEASE branch; grab it from CVS if you are in a hurry.

Having been up in redmond for an indoctrination week, and now that I am 
halfway through richters (excellent) CLR book, I realize that the reference 
model in this task is wrong. Really we should not be asking for a fileset of 
references, we should expect a list of libraries and a path to where they may 
be, ,ore like the lib model of C++ compilers than classpaths in java.

In the Ant1.6 timeframe, after we pull the <cc> task and datatypes into ant 
from sourceforge, I will look at re-using this tasks <libset> datatype so you 
can re-use lists of references in >1 <csc> task, just as you can with 
classpaths in <javac>. If you are in a hurry, you can start this without 
waiting for me...
creator: steve_l@iseran.com
stevel@apache.org

refiling as enhancement as the immediate problem is fixed, reworking the
